summary: This is an FBI Public Affairs News Briefing from July 29, 2020, summarizing major news stories of the day. It covers Attorney General William Barr's contentious House Judiciary Committee testimony, protests and federal response in Portland and other cities, various criminal investigations (including opposition to Ghislaine Maxwell's effort to name Epstein victims), counter-intelligence matters, and other Washington and international news. The document is a compilation of media reports and summaries, not a primary investigative record.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.role: Attorney General of the United States
persons.context: Testified before the House Judiciary Committee, defending federal response to protests, the DOJ's handling of cases involving Trump associates (Flynn, Stone), and the Durham investigation.

persons.name: Jerrold Nadler
persons.context: Chaired the hearing with AG Barr, accused Barr of distorting the Justice Department to serve President Trump's political agenda.

persons.name: Jim Jordan
persons.context: Defended AG Barr, decried the Russia probe as an effort to undermine Trump, and aired a video contrasting media descriptions of protests with violent footage.

persons.name: Michael Flynn
persons.context: Barr defended the DOJ's decision to drop charges against him and revealed an investigation into 'unmasking' requests during the Obama administration.

persons.name: Roger Stone
persons.context: Barr defended his intervention to recommend a shorter prison sentence for Stone, a Trump associate.

persons.name: John Bash
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Western District of Texas
persons.context: Appointed by Barr to investigate the 'high number of unmaskings' of Michael Flynn during the Obama administration.

persons.name: John Durham
persons.context: Leading an investigation into the origins of the Trump-Russia probe; Barr did not rule out the release of his report before the 2020 election.

persons.name: Nancy Pelosi
persons.context: Criticized Barr's testimony as 'despicable' and was accused by Barr of endangering law enforcement by comparing federal officers to 'stormtroopers.'

persons.name: Cedric Richmond
persons.context: Accused Barr and his predecessors (Sessions, Whitaker) of systemic racism for not bringing black staff to top DOJ positions.

persons.name: Mike Pence
persons.context: Criticized Democrats during the Barr hearing and credited President Trump for vaccine progress.

persons.name: Hank Johnson
persons.context: Sparred with AG Barr over the sentencing of Roger Stone, repeatedly interrupting him.

persons.name: Kayleigh McEnany
persons.context: Stated that Democrats' criticism of Barr is rooted in his probe of 'Russia-gate.'

persons.name: Kern Kupec
persons.context: Commented on Fox News that Democrats hurled allegations at Barr and refused to let him answer questions.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Federal prosecutors opposed her legal team's effort to name Jeffrey Epstein's victims in her criminal case.

persons.name: Peter Strzok
persons.context: Announced a book about his concerns that President Trump could be compromised, offering an insider view of the Russia investigation.

persons.name: Christopher Steele
persons.context: His dossier on Trump-Russia connections was discussed in a declassified Senate report highlighting doubts about its reliability.

persons.name: Igor Danchenko
persons.context: Identified as the primary sub-source for the Steele dossier; worked at the Brookings Institution.

persons.name: Valerie Jarrett
persons.role: Former Senior Adviser to President Obama
persons.context: Pressed about President Obama's role in the Russia probe, stated investigations are left to the intelligence community.

persons.name: Robert Mueller
persons.context: Subject of criticism in a new book by Norm Eisen for refusing to admit Trump committed 'chargeable crimes.'

persons.name: Norm Eisen
persons.context: Authored a book criticizing Robert Mueller for not going far enough in his obstruction of justice inquiry.

persons.name: Rick Singer
persons.context: The mastermind of the college admissions scandal was revealed to have been working on his own doctorate until recently.

persons.name: Larry Householder
persons.context: Subject of a federal bribery probe related to a nuclear bailout law; a former candidate revealed he was an FBI informant in the case.

persons.name: Nick Owens
persons.role: Former State Legislative Candidate, FBI Informant
persons.context: Revealed he went to the FBI with concerns about political ads in his race, becoming a witness in the Householder probe.

persons.name: Stephen Fogarty
persons.role: Lieutenant General, Commander of Army Cyber Command
persons.context: Outlined a ten-year plan for information warfare and the Army's cyber strategy.

connections.description: Contentious exchange during House Judiciary Committee hearing, with Nadler accusing Barr of serving Trump's agenda and Barr defending his actions.
Barr defended the DOJ's decision to drop charges against Flynn and initiated an investigation into the 'unmasking' of Flynn.
Barr defended his intervention to recommend a shorter prison sentence for Stone, a friend of President Trump.
Barr appointed Bash, a U.S. Attorney, to investigate the 'unmasking' of Michael Flynn.
Barr oversees Durham's investigation into the origins of the Trump-Russia probe and commented on the timing of its report.
Maxwell is accused of grooming underage girls for sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein.
Danchenko was the primary sub-source for the anti-Trump dossier compiled by former British spy Christopher Steele.
Owens acted as an FBI informant, providing information about Householder's political operation that contributed to the federal bribery probe.
Strzok, a former FBI agent, was a key figure in the Russia investigation and is publishing a book about his concerns regarding Trump.

events.title: Barr Testifies Before House Judiciary Committee
events.description: Attorney General William Barr testified before the House Judiciary Committee in a heated hearing, defending the federal response to protests, the DOJ's handling of cases involving Trump associates (Flynn, Stone), and the Durham investigation.

events.title: Federal Prosecutors Oppose Maxwell Naming Victims
events.description: Federal prosecutors filed opposition to Ghislaine Maxwell's effort to publicly name the underage girls she is accused of grooming for Jeffrey Epstein's sexual abuse.

events.title: Barr Reveals Unmasking Investigation
events.description: Attorney General Barr revealed he appointed U.S. Attorney John Bash to investigate the 'high number of unmaskings' of Michael Flynn during the Obama administration.

events.title: Senate Report on Steele Dossier Released
events.description: A declassified Senate Intelligence Committee report highlighted doubts about the reliability of the Steele dossier and internal debates between the CIA and FBI over its inclusion in intelligence assessments.

events.title: Protests and Federal Response in Portland
events.description: Continued violent protests at the federal courthouse in Portland, Oregon, with federal agents deployed. The ACLU sought contempt findings against federal officers, and the city fined the federal government for an unpermitted fence.

events.title: Former Candidate Reveals Role as FBI Informant
events.description: Former Ohio state legislative candidate Nick Owens revealed he was the FBI informant referenced in the federal charging documents against Ohio House Speaker Larry Householder in a bribery probe.

keyFacts: Attorney General William Barr testified before the House Judiciary Committee, defending federal actions in Portland, the dropping of charges against Michael Flynn, and the sentencing of Roger Stone.
Federal prosecutors opposed Ghislaine Maxwell's effort to name Jeffrey Epstein's victims in her criminal case.
AG Barr revealed he appointed U.S. Attorney John Bash to investigate the 'unmasking' of Michael Flynn during the Obama administration.

A declassified Senate Intelligence Committee report highlighted doubts about the reliability of the Steele dossier, with its primary sub-source identified as Igor Danchenko, a former Brookings Institution analyst.
Former Ohio candidate Nick Owens revealed he acted as an FBI informant in the bribery probe of Ohio House Speaker Larry Householder.
